thread.title: Frankel vows to 'clean up county'

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: Frankel vows to 'clean up county'
text:
Sandra Frankel likes to joke that she failed at retirement. Relaxing never really was part of her plan. She decided in 2011 against running for re-election as town supervisor in Brighton not so she could retire, but so she could challenge Republican Monroe County Executive Maggie Brooks for the region’s top elected office.
It’s been four years since she lost that race. Why is the Democrat giving it another shot?
Frankel says she still has a driving passion for public service and gets satisfaction from making an impact. She cheerfully recalls the thrill of victories like helping to shut down the Travelers Motel in Brighton, a magnet for crime, back in the mid-1990s.
Today, she sharply criticizes GOP leadership of the county for corruption, waste and mismanagement, and says she has a proven record as the "transformative leader" needed to turn things around.
ROCHESTER DEMOCRAT AND CHRONICLE
Dinolfo say she'll be a problem solver
“I’m going to clean up county government,” Frankel says.
Agree with her or not, Frankel has a lot to say about the county’s promise and problems, and she is eager to discuss her ideas in detail. She recently called a reporter to clarify the location of a specific parking lot that she thinks the county should stop leasing downtown.
On the campaign trail, voters — even some Republicans — are making clear they want a new direction, Frankel says.
“There is a genuine sense of frustration in the community that issues that are important in people’s lives aren’t being addressed,” she says.
Buy Photo Monroe County Executive candidate Sandra Frankel is greeted by Brighton resident Hollis Hames at a luncheon for UAW retirees at the Diplomat Banquet Center on Oct. 15. (Photo: LAUREN PETRACCA/@laurenpetracca/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)
Record in Brighton
Frankel has made her 20 years as Brighton supervisor the cornerstone of her campaign.
She says this experience — balancing the books, managing departments, overseeing community projects — sets her apart from her Republican opponent, Cheryl Dinolfo, who has been county clerk since 2004.
“While that serves a large number of people in the county, the experience is very limited because it’s a ministerial function,” Frankel says of the clerk position. “My experience is as a very successful CEO.”
Since Frankel has made much of her record, it’s little surprise that Republicans have, too.
ROCHESTER DEMOCRAT AND CHRONICLE
Rajesh Barnabas challenges status quo
A recent campaign flier funded by the Republican State Committee said that voters rejected Frankel in 2011 because of her “tax and spend record” as supervisor.
And in an interview this month, Dinolfo said that Frankel raised taxes 12 times in Brighton. Going after Frankel on tax issues makes sense as a strategy, says Curt Smith, a former speechwriter for President George H.W. Bush, an author and senior lecturer in English at the University of Rochester.
“If I’m the Dinolfo people, I’m spending what money I have in effect saying Sandy Frankel is out of the mainstream,” he says.
Frankel says in fact, she shored up a town that was "fraying at the edges" in financial terms.
She says she inherited a budget deficit and the threat of a credit rating downgrade that would have forced the town to pay higher interest to borrow money. She says in her first year, she froze spending, negotiated a wage freeze with unions and took smaller steps to reduce costs.
“In fact,” she says, “I’m fiscally conservative.”
That same year, however, the town raised its property tax rate by about 20 percent.
Frankel says she understands that figure may sound scary, but she describes it as one step among many to balance a long-mismanaged budget. She downplays the impact of that change — an increase of about $82 a year for a homeowner whose property was assessed at $100,000, she says.
“I wasn’t elected to eviscerate the essential services and programs that people in the community depended upon, wanted and needed,” Frankel says.
After that, the average annual tax rate increase in Brighton was at or below the rate of inflation, Frankel says. In some years, it declined as she eliminated redundant positions, she says. Other years, it rose because voters approved referendums for public infrastructure projects like the creation of a town-wide park system and sidewalk repairs.
Today, Brighton is more financially stable and the changes during her tenure reflect the town's values, Frankel says. “I’m proud of my record.”
It makes sense for Frankel to play to her experience, says Timothy Kneeland, history and political science chairman at Nazareth College and director of the Center for Public History.
“She’s a solid candidate and a good, solid member of the Democratic Party,” he says.
Buy Photo Idolo Madau of Gates shares a laugh with Monroe County executive candidate Sandra Frankel at a luncheon for UAW retirees at the Diplomat Banquet Center on Oct. 15. (Photo: LAUREN PETRACCA/@laurenpetracca/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)
Why politics?
Frankel grew up in Miami Beach, Florida, when racial segregation was the law.
That’s how it was in New Orleans, too, when Frankel attended Newcomb College of Tulane University. She says she participated in sit-ins to protest racist policies and was drawn to women’s equality, too.
That activism is where her interest in politics began.
“This instilled in me a desire to end discrimination, bias, prejudice and to work for equality for all,” Frankel says.
'Get our fiscal house in order'
Frankel says Monroe County is under deep financial strain.
She refers often to a state Comptroller’s Office report that said this is the most fiscally stressed county in New York. Outgoing County Executive Maggie Brooks largely blames the strain on unfunded state mandates.
Frankel says most counties are doing a better job managing the mandate problem.
“We have to get our fiscal house in order,” she says.
But she rules out a tax increase. Frankel says she can find and eliminate waste in the $1 billion budget and reinvest a portion of the savings in programs that matter.
Frankel admits she doesn’t have all the answers looking from the outside in.
But she offers a list of $4.2 million in potential savings in the county budget. Some ideas are fairly concrete, such as giving up leases for downtown parking lots and office space that Frankel doesn’t think the county needs.
Buy Photo Monroe County Executive candidate Sandra Frankel introduces herself to Sandi Giardino of Spencerport during a luncheon for UAW retirees at the Diplomat Banquet Center on Oct. 15. (Photo: LAUREN PETRACCA/@laurenpetracca/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)
Others are more tentative and would rely on renegotiating existing leases or contracts.
Frankel wants to tap $900,000 in anticipated savings and put it toward child care subsidies for working families in her first year, saying this will help parents to hold down jobs. Frankel also wants to tap $300,000 to create new offices of Public Integrity and Violence Prevention.
She also is optimistic that the local economy will grow, producing more tax revenue.
'Without integrity, you have nothing'
Frankel, like Dinolfo, says she wants to establish an Office of Public Integrity that will operate independently from her office, with authority to work directly with law enforcement.
Frankel takes her ethics pledge a step further by vowing not to accept campaign donations from county employees, nor any people or businesses with applications before the county. She also says family members of county department heads and senior county officials should be ineligible for county appointments and jobs.
In addition, Frankel says she wants all leases and contracts to be re-bid when they expire instead of automatically renewing them.
"Without integrity," she says, "you have nothing."
Frankel also is a longtime critic of local development corporations — nonprofit entities that the county created to finance major infrastructure projects.
The LDCs are at the center of a criminal case alleging that four men steered contracts for that work to well-connected bidders.
Frankel has backed past Democratic efforts to subject the LDCs to greater oversight by the County Legislature and require them to operate more openly. She questions whether a separate plan from Dinolfo to eliminate LDCs is realistic.
Targeting the right industries
Frankel says the county’s economic development arm needs to focus.
In her view, the County of Monroe Industrial Development Agency too often hands out tax breaks. For example, a law firm moving from downtown to Perinton shouldn’t get a tax abatement for its new offices, Frankel says.
Instead, COMIDA should focus on medium- and high-skill industries that show promise and pay good wages, including photonics and optics, green jobs and food production.
Frankel also wants to set up a $5 million low-interest loan program for small manufacturing and high-tech businesses, and a low-interest, forgivable loan program for Monroe Community College students who commit to work in targeted local industries for at least five years.
She sees her plans to boost child care subsidies for working parents as part of an economic development plan. She has pledged to try to double the number of children who receive county-subsidized child care and to lobby for more state and federal funding.
Frankel also wants to promote the region’s access to fresh water, saying it can benefit industry and will become more attractive as climate change brings worsening drought to other parts of the country.
"If people have hope and opportunities for good jobs, we'll see a reduction in crime and violence," Frankel says. "We'll see a reduction in poverty."
DRILEY@Gannett.com
Sandra Frankel
Age: 73.
Lives in: Brighton.
Hometown: Miami Beach, Florida.
Professional background: Brighton town supervisor, 1992-2012.
Speech language pathologist, 1968-1991
Frankel Associates (photography business), 2012-present
Education: Newcomb College of Tulane University, New Orleans, Louisiana; bachelor’s degree, psychology and philosophy.
Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois; master’s degree, speech pathology.
Stanford University and San Jose State College, California; graduate studies.
Other experience: Ten years with the Monroe County School Boards Association.
Six years on the Brighton school board.
Democratic nominee for lieutenant governor, 1998.
Democratic candidate for Monroe County executive, 2011.
Family: Married to Neil A. Frankel, retired research scientist and manager, Xerox; three children; nine grandchildren.
Party lines: Frankel will appear on the Democratic and Working Families party lines.
Group endorsements: Rochester NOW (National Organization of Women)
Planned Parenthood of Central and Western New York
NARAL Pro-Choice NY
Empire State Pride Agenda
Federation of Social Workers
Rochesterians Concerned About Unsafe Shale Gas Extraction
Monroe Community College Faculty Association
1199 SEIU
UAW Capital Region 9
Amalgamated Transit Union Local 282
Finger Lakes Police Federation
The Rochester & Vicinity Central Labor Council
The Eleanor Roosevelt Legacy Committee
International Association of Firefighters (IAFF), Rochester Local 1071
